questions.text:
Arrange the auditory pathway in order from periphery to centre

A. Eight nerve

B. Inferior colliculus

C. Medial geniculate body

D. Ventral / dorsal cochlear nucleus

E. Superior Olivary nucleus

F. Lateral lemniscus

G. Auditory cortex

Correct Answer (A)

A, D, E, F, B, C, G

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

Auditory pathway--ECOLI MA

E - Eight nerve

C- Ventral / dorsal cochlear nucleus

O - Superior Olivary nucleus

L - Lateral lemniscus

I - Inferior colliculus

M - Medial geniculate body

A - Auditory cortex

questions.text:
The facial recess (FR) is the route used in posterior tympanotomy to perform cochlear implantation surgery,Which of the following are anatomical boundaries of Facial recess?

1. Short process of Incus

2. Horizontal segment of facial nerve

3. Vertical segment of facial nerve

4. Chorda tympani nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,3 and 4

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanotomy.

• Medial boundary—vertical segment of fa cial nerve ( =mastoid segment) Lateral boundary—chorda tymapani

• Superior boundary—fossa incudis ( short process of incus)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glomus jugulare.

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Phelps sign refers to the erosion of the caroticojugular spine (the bony ridge between the carotid canal and jugular fossa), which is a characteristic finding on imaging (CT or MRI) in cases of glomus jugulare tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has a potential role in the etiology of otosclerosis (OS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Measles virus

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: 

• A number of findings point toward a viral etiology for OS. 

• Measles antigens and RNA, as well as nucleocapsid structures identical to measles virus have all been identified in OS lesions. 

• Increased levels of measles-specific 

• IgG have also been detected in the perilymph of OS patients undergoing stapedectomy. 

• It is not yet certain that the measles virus is in- volved in the development of OS, and the pathogenesis is yet to be elucidated

choices.text: Delayed onset, appearing several seconds after head positioning
Fatigable, becoming weaker with repetitions of the maneuver
Transience, usually lasting 40 seconds or less

questions.text: Posterior canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), provoked by the Dix– Hallpike maneuver, produces nystagmus with the following features except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vertical downbeating nystagmus

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo

1. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a disorder frequently seen in neurotologic practice and stems from loose otoconia in the posterior (most commonly), horizontal,or superior semicircular canals.

2. Intense vertigo is provoked by head position changes, such as rolling over in bed, lying down, or looking up.

3. Hallpike testing can make the diagnosis and determine the involved side in posterior canal BPPV.

The nystagmus of BPPV is pathognomonic:

• Several (2-to 10-) second latency

• Geotropic (beating toward the ground)

• Horizontal-rotary

• Lasts no more than 30 seconds before abating

• Fatigues with repetition of the hallpike maneuver.

Ref: Read the text below

• A prelingual deaf adult with no oral language is a poor cochlear-implant candidate.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

30-45 dB

Ref:Read the text below

Sol :  

• A prediction of the air bone gap can be made using tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz:

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates airbone gap of 20-30 dB.

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 30-45dB.

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 45-60 dB.

questions.text: A 50 year old female patient has presented with the complaint of long standing left ear discharge, foul smelling, blood stained. She has left sided facial palsy. She also gives history of ear ache which is worse at night. On otoscopy, friable granulations are seen in the middle ear. What is the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Malignancy of middle ear

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

Malignancy of middle ear

Patient often presents with clinical picture simulating chronic suppurative otitis media. However, the following features in age group of 40–60 years may arouse suspicion of malignancy:

- Chronic foul-smelling discharge especially when blood stained.

- Pain which is usually severe and comes at night.

- Facial palsy.

- Friable, haemorrhagic granulations or polyp.

- Appearance of or increase in hearing loss or vertigo.

questions.text: Finding shown in the given image is the hallmark findings of

Otomycosis

Sol:  

• This kind of appearance is seen in otomycosis. 

• This is the appearance of fungal mass in the EAC which appears as wet piece of paper

questions.text: Comment on the grade of retracted tympanic membrane shown in the image :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Grade I

Ref: Read the text below

Sol.

Toss classification is for retraction of pars flaccid and Sade classification is for retraction of pars tensa

Sade classification of retraction of pars tensa

Grade 1 – mild retraction

Grade 2—severe retraction—retracted TM touching incus or stapes

Grade 3—Atelectatic TM—TM touching promontory but moves on seigelisation

Grade 4---Adhesive TM--TM touching promontory, does not move on seigelisationos classification of pars flaccida

Tos classification of pars flaccida

Stage I: Pars flaccida is dimpled and is more retracted than normal. It is not adherent to the malleus.

Stage II: In this stage the retraction pocket is adherent to the handle of malleus. The full extent of the retraction pocket can be clearly seen.

Stage III: In this stage part of the retraction pocket may be hidden. There may also be associated erosion of the outer attic wall (scutum).

Stage IV: In this stage there is definite severe erosion of the outer attic wall. The extent of the retraction pocket cannot be clearly seen as most of it are hidden from the view.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presented with right ear discharge since 15 days. Clinical examination revealed chalky white keratin plug in right external auditory canal and posterior meatal wall bulge with dull tympanic membrane. Otoendoscopy shows wax with keratin debris as shown in the image.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Keratosis obturans

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Keratosis Obturans (Primary canal cholesteatoma)

• It is accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus

• Seen between 5 and 20 yrs of age (i.e. younger age as compared to cholesteatoma which is seen in middle age)

• May be U/L or Bilateral (occasionally)

• It may be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.

Clinical Features

• Pain in the ear (severe olalgia)

• Hearing loss (of conductive type)

• Tinnitus

• Ear discharge – sometimes

Grommet insertion with adenoidectomy is the treatment option for conductive deafness

questions.text: Given prosthesis is related with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Otosclerosis

Sol:

Stapedioplasty (see photograph)

In this diagram, the stapes has been removed, and a small piece of fat from the ear lobe has been used to "plug" the oval window and prevent perilymph from leaking into the middle ear. Gelfoam, temporalis fascia, vein and tragal perichondrium have all been successfully used in stapedectomy.

A Robinson stainless steel prosthesis is placed between the lenticular process of the incus and the fat plug in the oval window. The bucket handle of the prosthesis is rotated over the incus to prevent the prosthesis from slipping.

The system is finally tested by moving the malleus and incus with a Rosen needle and observing a corresponding movement in the light reflex of the fluid or blood accumulated in the round window niche. The movement of the light reflex confirms the integrity of the reconstructed osscular chain.

questions.text: A patient of left sided Meniere’s disease does not respond to conventional medical treatment. His episodes are becoming more frequent and he has developed severe sensorineural hearing loss on left side. Identify the treatment being rendered to patient in given picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Microwick assisted transtympanic Gentamicin Injection

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Primary treatment of meniere’s disease is medical management. Refractory patients are offered further treatments.

• If hearing is preserved , then vestibular neurectomy or endolymphatic sac decompression sur- geries can be done as they preserve hear- ing.
Meniete device is external device used for pulse pressure therapy to labyrinth.

• If hearing loss is significant, then trAn- stympanic injection of gentamicin using microwicks or microcatheters is prese- cribed.

• Alternatively surgical labyrinthec- tomy can be done. These procedures do not preserve hearing.

questions.text: 50 yrs old male patient suffering from  tubotympanic ear underwent surgery following which he developed tinnitus, vertigo, aural fullness, and disequilibrium .Choose the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perilymphatic fistula.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• A perilymphatic fistula (PLF) is an abnormal communication between the perilymph-filled inner ear and outside the inner ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window. PLF commonly causes cochlear and vestibular symptoms. 

• PLFs can broadly be divided into two categories: those with an identifiable cause and those without. 

• At first, PLFs were observed in post-stapedectomy patients where perilymph would leak around a prosthesis placed into the oval window due to a failure of the seal around or under the prosthesis

Seven years later, he began to experience vertigo, headache, and progressive loss of balance. After 2 years, audiometry showed moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear that has not been investigated. Study the given slide and comment on diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vestibular schwannoma

Ref:Read the text below.

Sol:-

Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas) and Other Cerebellopontine Angle Tumors

Acoustic Neuroma Histologic Types

1. Antoni Type A: histologically parallel nuclei, uniform spindle cells, compact cells

2. Antoni Type B: histologically less uniform, may have fatty or hyaline degeneration, less cellular

• Its presence is considered serious as it may indicate extradural or brain abscess.

• Sometimes, it is due to otitis externa associated with a discharging ear.

questions.text: Match the following :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

Ref:Read the text below

Sol

Type I Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations with a normal ossicular chain; recreates the middle ear space almost exactly to its native size and geometry

Type II Tympanoplasty
Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations where the malleus is partially eroded; the new tympanic membrane is coupled with or without the malleus remnant to the native incus

Type III Tympanoplasty
Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations involving defects of the malleus and incus; the new tympanic membrane is coupled to the capitulum of the stapes

Type IV Tympanoplasty
Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane and establishment of ossicular coupling to a mobile stapes footplate with absent crura; the new tympanic membrane is coupled to the footplate of the stapes

Type V Tympanoplasty
Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane and establishment of ossicular coupling to the scala vestibuli in situations involving a fixed stapedial footplate

questions.text:
Child with recurrent URTI, high arched palate, learning difficulty present with hearing loss.Tympanometry was done and findings are given in given tympanogram, choose the most appropriate treatment options

1. Myringotomy

2. Grommet insertion

3. Adenoidectomy

4. Tympanoplasty
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,2 and 3

Ref: Read the text below

Sol

Secretory (Serous) Otitis Media or Otitus Media With Effusion

Secretory (Serous) Otitis Media: persistence of fluid in the middle ear space without evidence of infection

Pathophysiology: may be from persistent fluid from suppurative acute otitis media (≈10% of acute otitis media cases have persistent fluid 3 months after resolution of the infection) or secondary to eustachian tube dysfunction

Symptoms: serous fluid in middle ear space (nonmobile TM, air-fluid levels), aural fullness, hearing loss, tinnitus

Traetment: observation (frequent autoinflation), management of nasal congestion (eg, decongestants, nasal corticosteroids), may consider myringotomy with grommet, and/or adenoidectomy after failed conservative measures, antimicrobials (similar to acute otitis media) reduce the risk of secondary infection.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency with high grade fever, seizure and altered sensorium. On examination hemianopia was documented. On history he was known case of CSOM and was under treatment. and was undergoing CSOM treatment. Immediate CT was done. Choose the most appropriate Diagnosis ?

Otogenic Brain Abscess:

- Temporal lobe abscess: Cerebellar abscess = 2:1.

- Organisms: Commonest: Anaerobic streptococci.

- Nominal Aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, focal epilepsy.

Mastoidectomy:

Canal wall down (CWD) procedures:

• Modified radical mastoidectomy

• Radical mastoidectomy

• Atticotomy

Canal wall up (CWU) procedures:

• Cortical mastoidectomy (Schwartz operation)

Combined approach tympanoplasty

questions.text: Blood stained foul smelling chronic ear discharge with otoscopy findings given in the image,What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Primary aquired cholesteatoma

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Cholesteatoma is presence of skin in mid- dle ear cleft. It is pearly white in clour. It has 4 types of origins.

• Most common origin is Primary acquired cholesteatoma which is due to retraction pocket ( as shown in the image). Retraction pockets are more common in Pars Flaccida.

• Secondary acquired Cholesteatoma are due to marginal perforation.

• Tertiary acquired is due to implantation of skin in middle ear during surgery or accidental trauma

• Congenital cholesteatoma is since birth. It presents with pearly white mass behind intact TM

questions.text: The picture given is an ossicular replacement prosthesis used in a situation when there is erosion of Malleus, Incus and stapes Head. What is the name of this prosthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Total ossicular replacement prosthesis

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• PORP ( Partial ossicular replacement pros- thesis) is used in Type III tympanoplasty situation when malleus and incus are ab- sent

• TORP ( Total ossicular replacement pros- thesis) is used in Type IV tympanoplasty situation when malleus , incus and sta- pes head are absent and only footplate is there

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lupus vulgaris

Reference: Read the text below

Sol:    

• Lupus vulgarise ear – Turkey Ear – Cutaneous manifestation of tuberculosis.

• Classical lupus lesions are often seen in head & neck regions

• Characteristic sign – reddish indurated plaque lesions involving earlobe

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about tubercular otitis media
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Always blood-stained ear discharge

Reference: Read the text below

Sol:    

It is secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis, reaches middle ear through Eust tube. Sometimes it is blood borne.

Clinical features:

•   Painless otorrhoea

•   Fails to respond to topical treatment

•   Pale exuberant granulations

•  Some  patients show multiple tympanic membrane perforation.

•   Hearing loss is greater than what may be otherwise accepted, conductive usually

•   Facial palsy  common complication 

Treatment:

 Modfied radical mastoidectomy and ATT

questions.text: A 59 year old lady presenting with bulging tympanic mass which blanches on pressing neck vessels (Given image). There is a clinical suspicion of glomus jugulare in this patient. Which of the following will not be in the list of planned investigations in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Biopsy for histopathological diagnosis

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Glomus jugulare is a variety of paragan- glinoma which originates from glomus cells lying around the jugular bulb. It is more common in females It’s a benign non capsulated locally invasive tumour. It is a highly vascular tumour of skull base which leads to pulsatie tinnitus.

• It erodes the floor of middle ear and start appearing in the middle ear in the hypotympanum as red vascular mass (Rising sun sign). When it enters EAC, there is bleeding from ear canal.

• Brown sign is on otoscopy when tumour blanches on seigelisation.

• It spreads on skull base which leads to erosion of septum between carotid canal and jugular foramen (Phelp sign). It can cause 7,9 10, 11, 12 cranial nerve palsy. Biopsy is contraindicated.

• Since it is a variety of paraganglionoma ( other eg. Pheochromocytoma)—therefore urinary VMA levels should be done.

• Preoperative embolisation helps toreduce blood loss during surgery.

FISCH CLASSIFICATION

choices.text: HRCT temporal bone is helpful in diagnosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with vertigo induced by sound or pressure. Subsequent investigation revealed dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal and the patient underwent a surgical repair. All are characteristic features of superior semicircular canal dehiscence except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sensorineural hearing loss on audiometry

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Superior semicircular canal dehiscence is either traumatic or congenital. Patient complains of vertigo especially on hearing loud sounds (tullio’s phenomenon).

• Patient shows conductive hearing loss on audiometry due to leakage of sound energy from third window which has been created in SCC (apart from oval and round window). This is called third window phenomenon

• HRCT temporal bone is the diagnostic investigation. Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) is also helpful in its diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient developed sudden hearing loss on right side within a span of 12 hours. On audiometry, the right ear has 70dB sensor hearing loss over 500,1000 and 2000 Hz. What is the best management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oral steroids

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• It’s a case of Sudden SNHL.

• A commonly used criterion to qualify for this diagnosis is a sensorineural hearing loss of greater than 30 dB over 3 contiguous pure-tone frequencies occurring within 3 
days’ period. 

• Usually it presents as unilateral loss of hearing; bilateral involvement is rare

questions.text: The given investigation in the picture checks the function of which structure of inner ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Saccule

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

In VEMP, we stimulate the saccule with loud sound and we record the contractions of Sternocleidomastoid muscle (Vestibulocollic reflex). This test checks the inferior vestibular division of 8th nerve as saccule is supplied by this nerve.

questions.text: Otalgia is the sensation of pain in the ear, while referred otalgia is pain felt in the ear but originating from a nonotologic source. The rich sensory innervation of the ear derives from four cranial nerves and two cervical nerves which also supply other areas in the head and  neck.Which of the following cause referred otalgia through Vagus nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pyriform sinus cancer

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• A, B and C choices cause referred ear ache through Glossopharyngeal nerve

• Supraglottic cancer and pyriform sinus cancer cause referred ear ache through Vagus nerve

• Dental and TM Joint diseases cause referred ear ache through Trigeminal nerve

questions.text: Identify the maneuver given in image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dix Hallpike’s maneovure

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

BPPV

Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of macula. Macula is the sensory end organ of utricle and saccule whose function is linear acceleration.

BPPV

• Displaced otoconia from macula is the aetiology

• Most commonly otoliths come to lie in posterior semicircular canal

Dix hallpike’s test is diagnostic test of BPPV

questions.text: Sound Bridge Device provides recipients with natural sound quality without feedback. That’s its unique design can be coupled to the most appropriate middle ear structure to suit each individual recipient’s specific anatomy. Identify the parts of the Sound Bridge Device
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A= Receiver B=Conductor link C=transducer

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• The Sound Bridge Device consists of an external part, the audio processor (AP) and an implanted part, the vibrating ossicular prosthesis (VORP).

• The AP is worn on the head and contains a microphone, a digital signal processor and a battery.

• The VORP consists of a receiver/stimulator, a conductor link, and a transducer

questions.text: Where does to given sinus drain into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Infundibulum

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol: 

• The maxillary sinus, the largest of the sinuses, is within the body of the maxilla. 

• It is shaped like a pyramid; its base is usually medial, with its apex in the zygomatic process of the maxilla. Its roof is the floor of the orbit, and its floor is the alveolar process of the maxilla. 

• The maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus by means of the semilunar hiatus. 

• The floor of the maxillary sinus is slightly below the level of the nasal cavity, and it is related to the upper teeth

• Maxillary sinusitis is frequently accompanied by toothache. Infection may spread among the various sinuses, the nasal cavity, and the teeth. 

• The opening of the maxillary sinus can be cannulated in vivo through the nostril.

questions.text: Which of the following is appropriate statement about pathology shown in given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pain and bleeding from nose are the characteristic clinical features

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Mucormycosis (rhinocercbral phycomycosis):

1. Is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection

2. Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopus oryzae

3.  Predisposing factors: immunosuppressed patients, uncontrolled young diabetics

Features:

1. Remarkable affinity for blood vessels- arteries

2. Leads to extensive endothelial damage & thrombosis

Findings:

The disease begins in the nose, invade  P.N.S  orbit  cribiform plate meninges brain

Typical Finding

1. Black necrotic mass seen filling the entire nasal cavity

2. Erosion of the nasal septrum and the hard palate may be appreciable

There is anesthesia over face, nose with reduced mucosal bleeding

M.R.I. Detects early vascular and intracranial invasion

Treatment:

• Systemic amphotericin ( Liposomal)

• Local drainage and debridement

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of a foreign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. After a clinical diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis, he underwent complete excision of the mass after bipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis. Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinosporodiosis

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

Rhinosporidiosis:

Organism: Rhinosporidium seeberi. Distribution: India (Southern parts), Sri lanka.

Sites of Affection:

Most commonly: Nose and Nasopharynx Mulberry shaped polypoidal mass studded with white dots or sporangia on its under surface.

Site: Vestibule (septal area).

Treatment:

Complete excision of the mass with a cutting diathermy and cauterization of its base.

Medical management: Local injection of corticosteroids and courses of dapsone and amphotericin.

• It can be a variety of shapes, most commonly using the inverted V incision or a stairstep incision.

questions.text: 40  yr old female  presents in ENT OPD  complaining of nasal obstruction and presence of crusts, mucopurulent rhinorrhea and breathing difficulties since last month. On examination foul smelling black crust was seen in nasal cavity. Which of the following finding can be associated with merciful anosmia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Roomy cavity

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Atrophic rhinitis (OZAENA):

• Progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and the underlying bone of the turbinate and the presence of viscid secretions which from foul smelling crusts and roomy cavities.

• Klebsiella ozaenae (Perez bacillus), Diphtheriods and Bacillus mucosus.

• Usually starts in females.

• Around puberty.

Treatment:

Medical:

• Alkaline douching

(Alkaline solution: - 280 ml warm water + a teaspoonful of the following powder: * Sodium bicarbonate (28.4g) + Sodium biborate (28.4g) + Sodium chloride (56.7g).

• Glucose in glycerine.

• Kemicetine antiozaena solution.

• Chloramphenicol.

• Estradiol dipropionate.

• Vitamin D2.

• Human placental extract: tissue therapy with systemic human placenta extract

Surgical Treatment:

Young’s operation:

• Closure of the nostril following elevation of the nasal vestibular folds.

Modified Young’s operation:

• Partial closure of the nostril leaving behind a 3mm hole.

• This remains for a period of 2 years.

Lautenslager’s operation:

• Surgical procedures aimed at medializing the lateral nasal wall.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child·presented with a unilateral single polyp. It does not bleed. What will be your line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

)Investigate for intranasal meningocele

Ref.: Read the text below 

Sol : 

• Simple nasal polypi below 2 years of age are rare. 

• Meningocele, meningoencephalocele or a glioma can present as a unilateral polyp and biopsy would risk meningitis. 

• Such a child requires CT scan/MRI to establish an intracranial connection and later a neurosurgical approach for removal.

questions.text: Uppermost extent of the nose as determined by direct visual inspection :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radix.

Sol:

• The glabella is the point that marks a smooth prominence on the frontal bone _1 to 1.5 cm above the radix of the nose.

• The radix is the uppermost extent of the nose as determined by direct visual inspection.

• The nasion is a depression just cephalad to the radix that marks the nasofrontal angle.

• The rhinion is the junction between the bony and cartilaginous dorsum.

questions.text: Asymmetrical Congestive Response (The Nasal Cycle) occurs every:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2–4 hours 

Sol:

Regulation Response Types

1. Asymmetrical Congestive Response (The Nasal Cycle): Normal physiological congestion/decongestion cycle alternating between nasal sides every 2–4 hours

2. Symmetrical Congestive Response: temporary bilateral congestion induced by exercise, changes in body position, hyperventilation, cold air, sulfur, histamine, and other irritants; lasts 15–30 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fungal balls are most common in Ethmoid sinus

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Fungal balls or aspergilloma are most commonly seen in maxillary sinus. 

• Mucocecles are most common in frontal sinus. Osteomas are most common in frontal sinus. 

• Malignancy is most common in maxillary sinus.

• Ethmoid bone is a single bone which lies between two orbits. 

• Therefore, ethmoid sinusitis is most likely to cause orbital infection.

questions.text: Study the given image ,growth of which half in maxillary sinus has worse prognosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Superior.

Reference: Internet

Sol. 

The maxillary sinuses are a subset of the paranasal sinuses and can generally be thought of as the sinuses, or cavities, beneath the cheeks and on the sides of the nose. The maxillary sinuses are the most common region that paranasal sinus cancer arises, and most cancers in the maxillary sinuses are squamous cell carcinomas, meaning they arise from flat, thin cells in the epidermis lining the maxillary sinus.

OHNGREN'S CLASSIFICATION

• An imaginary plane is drawn extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible.

• Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

• According to Oghren's principle,growth above Oghren's Line has worse prgnosis.

• Depending on the type and stage of the tumors, maxillary sinus cancers are usually treated with surgery and radiation, and in advanced cases chemotherapy.

choices.text: Intralesional Cidofovir is helpful to reduce the recurrence rate
Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser is the primary modality of treatment

questions.text: Given investigation of larynx is based on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rigid endoscopy of larynx with flashing light

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Stroboscopy

• This is an excellent tool for examining the movements of the vocal cords  in their various phases.Stroboscopic images are generated  using a flashing light source create the illusion of slow motion Strobolaryngoscopy takes advantage of these principles by producing intermittent light flashes in close relation to the frequency of the vocal-fold vibration. 

• A microphone picks up the frequency of the examinee's sustained voice, which triggers the stroboscopic light source. 

• With the provision that the vocal vibrations are periodic, a frequency of light flashes equal to the vocal frequency produces a clear, still image of the same portion to the vibratory cycle.

questions.text: Structures passing between upper border of superior constrictor muscle and base of skull Include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tensor tympani

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:    

• Tensor tympani, as the name indicates, is a muscle of the middle car. II enters the middle ear through canal for tensor tympani. Its tendon hooks round the processus cochleariformis, turns 90° laterally and gels attached 10 the neck of malleus. 

• Structures which pass between base of skull and superior constrictor muscle are: (i) Levator (veli) palatini (ii) Tensor (veli) palatini 

• (iii) Eustachian tube (iv) Ascending palatine artery (branch of facial artery) (v) Ascending pharyngeal artery (branch of exterior carotid)

questions.text:
A 53-year-old female noted a lump in the right side of her neck, which continued to enlarge. She presented with a 5-day history of inability to talk, and difficult and painful swallowing of both liquid and food. On physical examination, the patient appeared pale, dehydrated, anxious, and sick. Her past medical history was notable for hypertension and occasional alcohol intake.

Oral examination revealed an abundance of secretion, which was removed by suction, unilateral enlarged tonsil obstructing 95% of the oral cavity, an edematous uvula with slight deviation to the left, and a congested and edematous soft palate.


Select the most appropriate Diagnosi
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Malignancy

Ref: Read the text below

Sol : 

• Tonsillar SCC occurs most often in the 5th to 7th decades, and is more common in males than females (2:1 ratio). 

• The tumor commonly presents clinically as a painless neck mass. 

• Although paraneoplastic syndromes including SIADH, Cushing's syndrome and Eaton-Lambert myasthenic syndrome have been associated with head and neck SCC, there are no reports of these syndromes being associated with tonsillar SCC . 

• Besides the locoregional spread to cervical lymph nodes, the tumor metastasizes most commonly to liver, lungs, bones, brain and skin

questions.text: 50 yrs old male presented with odynophagia, “hot potato” voice and stridor.On examination diffuse swelling over the posterior pharyngeal wall was seen. X-ray revealed increased retropharyngeal space. Most suspected diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prevertebral abscess.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Prevertebral abscess presents with diffuse swelling while retropharyngeal abscess presents with localized swelling.

choices.text: Lateral soft tissue x-ray shows swollen epiglottis
Direct fibre optic laryngoscopy shows 'Pale epiglottis".
Inspiratory dyspnea is the hallmark feature

questions.text: A 8 yrs old patient presents with fever, sore throat and difficulty to swallow. His radiograph is given below. All of the following statements are true except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Direct fibre optic laryngoscopy shows 'Pale epiglottis".

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

Acute epiglottitis (Supraglottic laryngitis)

• It is a serious condition and affects children of 2-7 years of age but can also affect adults.

• Streptococcus  is the most common organism responsible for this condition in children.

• Lateral soft tissue x-ray of neck may show swollen epiglottis.(Thumb sign)

• Adults present with sorethroat & dysphagia

• Inspiratory dyspnea is the hallmark feature

choices.text: Gives a nibbled appearance due to ulceration of the free cord margin.
Is characterized by a 'wash-leather' ulceration of the epiglottis.

questions.text: Most appropriate statement regarding pathology shown in given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Is a precancerous condition.

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

• Repeated stripping of the cords is the usual practice unless frank carcinoma supervenes. 

• Nibbled appearance due to ulceration of the free cord margin is characteristic of tuberculous laryngitis. 

• 'Wash-leather' ulceration of the epiglottis appearance is seen in the tertiary form of acquired syphilis and represents the gummatous lesion. 

• There is a significant risk of progression to carcinoma in situ and frank invasive carcinoma.

choices.text: The rima glottidis is the interval between the false cords.
Keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium lines the true cords.
The posterior part of the ventricular sinus contains the mucus secreting saccule.
The paraglottic and pre-epiglottic spaces are continuous.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding anatomy of  larynx
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The paraglottic and pre-epiglottic spaces are continuous. 

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

• The rima glottidis is the interval Between the true cords.

• Has an anterior intermembranous part and a posterior intercartilaginous section.

• Non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium lines the true cords

• The saccule is located in the anterior part of the sinus. Its secretion constantly lubricates the vocal cords.

• The paraglottic and pre-epiglottic spaces are continuous Important in the spread of tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following is treated principally by voice therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vocal fold nodules

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

• Vocal fold nodules most commonly develop from chronic vocal fold misuse


• It is a common misperception that ones voice should be hoarse or rough after a long day of use. Most people are usually not aware that they are misusing their voice in these instances.

• Oftentimes, nodules develop in individuals that either start off with improper voice technique or subsequently develop it during periods of stressful voice use.

• Another common scenario is development of improper technique during an illness to compensate for a weakened voice. In any case, timely treatment is suggested to avoid permanent damage to the voice.

• The gold standard treatment for vocal fold nodules is voice therapy from a qualified voice therapist.

questions.text: Children with congenital anterior laryngeal webs should undergo genetic testing for abnormalities of which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

22

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

                                         LARYNGEAL WEB / ATRESIA

• Anterior congenital laryngeal webs typically cause aphonia or stridor. Occasionally a minor web will present as hoarseness in an older child.

• The Cohen classification of glottic webs is as follows: 

Type 1: <35% obstruction (mild hoarseness)

Type 2: 35% to 50% obstruction (hoarse, weak cry, stridor  with exertion)

Type 3: 50% to 75% obstruction (severe hoarseness, moderate airway obstruction)

Type 4: 75% to 90% obstruction (aphonia, severe airway obstruction)

• The most severe form of a laryngeal web is total atresia of the larynx. 

• Anterior laryngeal webs may be associated with deletions of chromosome 22q11.2 (velocardiofacial syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, Shprintzen syndrome).

questions.text: A 55 year old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total laryngectomy

Ref:Read the text below

Sol :  

• The given image shows a post-operative stump created for breathing in patients undergoing total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma. 

• In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx is removed. 

• The pharyngeal wall is repaired and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Upper airway examination

Ref:Read the text below

Sol :  

The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions-

1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction

2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space

3. Uses a cuff to protect the airway from secretions

4. Allows suction of secretions in impaired cough reflex

5. Allows administration of anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is currently the most common indication for tracheotomy in the pediatric population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Respiratory failure and ventilator dependence

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: 

• The three main indications for tracheotomy in the pediatric population are respiratory failure and anticipated need for prolonged ventilation, upper airway obstruc- tion, and providing access for pulmonary toilet

COTTON MYER.

Heimlich maneuver

Ref: Read the text below

questions.text: A male in 2nd decade of life has multiple recurrent nasal bleeding with recurrent nasal blockage. On endoscopy following image seen , and Contrast enhanced CT revealed a large, ill-defined enhancing soft tissue mass filling the chonae,nasopharynx and bilateral nasal cavity.Which of the following is contraindicated in the patient :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Debulking of the tumor 

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: 

• Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. 

• It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. 

• Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 

• Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss.

• Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.

• Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision

choices.text: Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Shift patient to OT and cautery.
Use hemostatic agents do 3 to 4 gargles per day

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Primary haemorrhage. 

• Occurs at the time of operation.

• It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 

• Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.

• Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).

Secondary haemorrhage. 

• Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 

• It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate indication of the drug shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Subglottic stenosis

Reducing postoperative granulation and scar tissue formation.

• An anti-cancer antibiotic 

• Anti-inflammatory actions also

- Airway stenoses
- Pharyngeal /Ose Stenosis 
- Head Neck Keloid
- After Myringotomy
- Nasal synechia 
- Choanal Atresia 
- Nasopahryngeal Carcinoma

choices.text: Anterior Jugular veins and inferior thyroid veins are the most common site of bleeding
In pediatric tracheostomy, a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall is never removed
High tracheostomy is indicated in carcinoma larynx.
Dead space is increased  in tracheostomy.

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding the tube shown below except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dead space is increased  in tracheostomy.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• High trachestomy means when it starts from first ring. It is only done in a case of cancer larynx. Otherwise, the level of tracheostomy is 2nd and 3rd rings. 

• If we involve first ring, it can cause subglottic stenosis later on. 

• In pediatric trachestomy, we don’t remove circular ring of anterior tracheal wall because this can lead to tracheomalacia later on. 

• In adults we do remove a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall to place the tube.

choices.text: Make patient NPO (nil per os) and place an nasogastric tube
Since it is terminal, no treatment is warranted

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with terminal lung cancer is unable to eat due to aspiration. He would like an opportunity to eat. Examination demonstrates left vocal cord paralysis. Which of the following is probably the most appropriate recommendation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vocal fold augmentation 

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

Vocal fold augmentation is the best initial choice of management. It is mini- mally invasive and may provide the ability for this patient to eat. Although Answer B would also be helpful, it is a much more aggressive intervention and not the first line of treatment.

questions.text: A 70 years old male presented with conductive deafness in left ear.His left tympanic membrane appears dull.On examination he has 3 cms enlarged cervical lymph node.On tympanometry,type B tympanogram is seen.Most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nasopharyngeal cancer.

Sol:   

NASOPHARYNGEAL CANCER

SSx: neck mass (most common initial symptom, 70%), serous otitis media from eustachian tube obstruction (second most common presentation, 50%), nasal obstruction, cranial nerve palsies (abducens nerve most common cranial nerve palsy), recurrent epistaxis, trismus, headache

Epstein-Barr Virus Association

• Early Intracellular Antigen (EA): early intracellular antigen

• Viral Capsule Antigen (VCA): late antigen, most specific immunological finding in nasopharyngeal cancer

questions.text: Improvement in nasal patency by retracting the lateral part of the cheek and thus testing the vestibular component of nose is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cottle’s test 

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol: 

• It is used in nasal obstruction due to abnormality of the nasal valve. 

• In this test, cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

• If the nasal airway improves on the teat side. 

• The test is positive and indicates abnormality of the vestibular component of nasal valve.
